content.webTitle: Child protection chiefs damned in Ofsted inspector's report

fields.headline: Child protection chiefs damned in Ofsted inspector's report
fields.bodyText: Child protection bosses must show “political and moral courage” to tackle widespread child sexual abuse in Britain’s towns and cities, despite intense pressure on budgets, the chief inspector of schools, Sir Michael Wilshaw has warned. The head of Ofsted says in his annual review of children’s social care that too many councils are still neither sufficiently alert to the problem of sexual exploitation locally nor suitably equipped to provide services able to respond. Wilshaw said child abuse scandals in Rotherham and elsewhere had shown that the strong leadership required in this field of child protection work was frequently lacking. “Faced with such shocking crimes, senior leaders must show political and moral courage. They must never allow misguided beliefs about the impact for certain ethnic and cultural groups to get in the way of confronting this horrific abuse wherever it occurs,” he says. A report into sexual exploitation of children in Rotherham, South Yorkshire last year found police and council officials failed to act on evidence that abuse was being committed on a wide scale by mostly Asian men. Organised child abuse has also been uncovered in Rochdale, Derby and Oxfordshire. But Wilshaw admitted that Ofsted inspectors had also failed to take abuse of children by criminal gangs seriously enough. Its inspection of Rotherham’s child protection arrangements in 2012 was, he said, “not good enough.” The review reveals that three-quarters of the 43 local authority child protection departments inspected during 2013-14 were found to be inadequate or requiring improvement. Just 10 were rated good. Wilshaw pointed out that child protection services were experiencing stark increases in demand at a time when the government was making large cuts to council budgets, putting intense pressure on safeguarding services. The review found that in 2013-14: The number of children in need in England increased by 5% to 397,600 Children on child protection plans increased by 12% to 48,300 The number of youngsters being looked after by councils rose by 1% and is at its highest level since 1987 Wilshaw said: “Social care professionals are often expected to do more with the same or less, all the while knowing that the actions they take and the decisions they make can dramatically change the course of a child’s life. “Growing public scrutiny and criticism only adds to that pressure. I make no apology for Ofsted carrying out robust inspections of these services on behalf of the children and young people who use them. “But we must recognise the context and constraints within which social workers and their managers work. They have a difficult and demanding role and do not always get the support and recognition they deserve.” Almost half of the children defined as in need in 2013-14 were assessed as at risk of abuse or neglect. A fifth were deemed to suffer from “family dysfunction”. The review adds: “It is likely that Ofsted inspections of local authorities will continue to identify unmet need and limited support for families and children, unless rising demand is matched by new resource or new solutions.” It identifies high turnover of frontline social workers and widespread problems recruiting experienced staff. Consistency of leadership is a problem, it says, with one in three local authorities changing their director of social services last year. Cllr David Simmonds, chairman of the local government association’s children and young people board, said the report demonstrated the pressure the child protection system was under. “Children’s services are creaking under the strain as they work to protect the most vulnerable children from abuse, neglect and child sexual exploitation,” he said. “In an NHS system failing to cope with winter pressures, the government recently pledged £2bn to alleviate the crisis. We need Whitehall to redress the balance and give us adequate resources we need to get on with the vital job of protecting children. “High-profile crimes of abuse and neglect have brought sharply into focus the need for vigilance. As a result, there are rightly thousands more children on the radar of social services now. But this is in a climate where councils have faced cuts to their budgets of 40% since 2010.” A Department for Education spokesperson said: “Nothing is more important than keeping children safe. That’s why we have worked relentlessly to transform the life chances of our most vulnerable children and our plan is working – something this report makes clear. “We have recruited more social workers than ever before; for the first time ever, children’s homes are required to prove how they’re supporting children to thrive both inside and outside the home; we’ve introduced tough new rules on councils to interview children who return from going missing within 72 hours and are intervening in 25 councils to ensure children are receiving the services they deserve.”
